segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide (Windows 10)
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide (Windows 10)

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security is a host firewall that helps secure the device in two ways.
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security is a host firewall that helps secure the device in two ways.

segment.source: First, it can filter the network traffic permitted to enter the device from the network, and also control what network traffic the device is allowed to send to the network.
segment.target: First, it can filter the network traffic permitted to enter the device from the network, and also control what network traffic the device is allowed to send to the network.

segment.source: Second, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security supports IPsec, which enables you to require authentication from any device that is attempting to communicate with your device.
segment.target: Second, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security supports IPsec, which enables you to require authentication from any device that is attempting to communicate with your device.

segment.source: When authentication is required, devices that cannot authenticate cannot communicate with your device.
segment.target: When authentication is required, devices that cannot authenticate cannot communicate with your device.

segment.source: By using IPsec, you can also require that specific network traffic be encrypted to prevent it from being read or intercepted while in transit between devices.
segment.target: By using IPsec, you can also require that specific network traffic be encrypted to prevent it from being read or intercepted while in transit between devices.

segment.source: The interface for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security is much more capable and flexible than the consumer-friendly interface found in the Windows Firewall Control Panel.
segment.target: The interface for Windows Firewall with Advanced Security is much more capable and flexible than the consumer-friendly interface found in the Windows Firewall Control Panel.

segment.source: They both interact with the same underlying services, but provide different levels of control over those services.
segment.target: They both interact with the same underlying services, but provide different levels of control over those services.

segment.source: While the Windows Firewall Control Panel meets the needs for protecting a single device in a home environment, it does not provide enough centralized management or security features to help secure more complex network traffic found in a typical business enterprise environment.
segment.target: While the Windows Firewall Control Panel meets the needs for protecting a single device in a home environment, it does not provide enough centralized management or security features to help secure more complex network traffic found in a typical business enterprise environment.

segment.source: For more overview information about Windows Firewall with Advanced Security and see Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: For more overview information about Windows Firewall with Advanced Security and see Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: About this guide
segment.target: About this guide

segment.source: This guide provides recommendations to help you to choose or create a design for deploying Windows Firewall with Advanced Security in your enterprise environment.
segment.target: This guide provides recommendations to help you to choose or create a design for deploying Windows Firewall with Advanced Security in your enterprise environment.

segment.source: The guide describes some of the common goals for using Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and then helps you map the goals that apply to your scenario to the designs that are presented in this guide.
segment.target: The guide describes some of the common goals for using Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and then helps you map the goals that apply to your scenario to the designs that are presented in this guide.

segment.source: This guide is intended for the IT professional who has been assigned the task of deploying firewall and IPsec technologies on an organization's network to help meet the organization's security goals.
segment.target: This guide is intended for the IT professional who has been assigned the task of deploying firewall and IPsec technologies on an organization's network to help meet the organization's security goals.

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security should be part of a comprehensive security solution that implements a variety of security technologies, such as perimeter firewalls, intrusion detection systems, virtual private networking (VPN), IEEE 802.1X authentication for wireless and wired connections, and IPsec connection security rules.
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security should be part of a comprehensive security solution that implements a variety of security technologies, such as perimeter firewalls, intrusion detection systems, virtual private networking (VPN), IEEE 802.1X authentication for wireless and wired connections, and IPsec connection security rules.

segment.source: To successfully use this guide, you need a good understanding of both the capabilities provided by Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and how to deliver configuration settings to your managed devices by using Group Policy in Active Directory.
segment.target: To successfully use this guide, you need a good understanding of both the capabilities provided by Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, and how to deliver configuration settings to your managed devices by using Group Policy in Active Directory.

segment.source: You can use the deployment goals to form one of these Windows Firewall with Advanced Security designs, or a custom design that combines elements from those presented here:
segment.target: You can use the deployment goals to form one of these Windows Firewall with Advanced Security designs, or a custom design that combines elements from those presented here:

segment.source: Basic firewall policy design.
segment.target: Basic firewall policy design.

segment.source: Restricts network traffic in and out of your devices to only that which is needed and authorized.
segment.target: Restricts network traffic in and out of your devices to only that which is needed and authorized.

segment.source: Domain isolation policy design.
segment.target: Domain isolation policy design.

segment.source: Prevents devices that are domain members from receiving unsolicited network traffic from devices that are not domain members.
segment.target: Prevents devices that are domain members from receiving unsolicited network traffic from devices that are not domain members.

segment.source: Additional "zones" can be established to support the special requirements of some devices, such as:
segment.target: Additional "zones" can be established to support the special requirements of some devices, such as:

segment.source: A "boundary zone" for devices that must be able to receive requests from non-isolated devices.
segment.target: A "boundary zone" for devices that must be able to receive requests from non-isolated devices.

segment.source: An "encryption zone" for devices that store sensitive data that must be protected during network transmission.
segment.target: An "encryption zone" for devices that store sensitive data that must be protected during network transmission.

segment.source: Server isolation policy design.
segment.target: Server isolation policy design.

segment.source: Restricts access to a server to only a limited group of authorized users and devices.
segment.target: Restricts access to a server to only a limited group of authorized users and devices.

segment.source: Commonly configured as a zone in a domain isolation design, but can also be configured as a stand-alone design, providing many of the benefits of domain isolation to a small set of devices.
segment.target: Commonly configured as a zone in a domain isolation design, but can also be configured as a stand-alone design, providing many of the benefits of domain isolation to a small set of devices.

segment.source: Certificate-based isolation policy design.
segment.target: Certificate-based isolation policy design.

segment.source: This design is a complement to either of the previous two designs, and supports any of their capabilities.
segment.target: This design is a complement to either of the previous two designs, and supports any of their capabilities.

segment.source: It uses cryptographic certificates that are deployed to clients and servers for authentication, instead of the Kerberos V5 authentication used by default in Active Directory.
segment.target: It uses cryptographic certificates that are deployed to clients and servers for authentication, instead of the Kerberos V5 authentication used by default in Active Directory.

segment.source: This enables devices that are not part of an Active Directory domain, such as devices running operating systems other than Windows, to participate in your isolation solution.
segment.target: This enables devices that are not part of an Active Directory domain, such as devices running operating systems other than Windows, to participate in your isolation solution.

segment.source: In addition to descriptions and example for each design, you will find guidelines for gathering required data about your environment.
segment.target: In addition to descriptions and example for each design, you will find guidelines for gathering required data about your environment.

segment.source: You can then use these guidelines to plan and design your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security deployment.
segment.target: You can then use these guidelines to plan and design your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security deployment.

segment.source: After you read this guide, and finish gathering, documenting, and mapping your organization's requirements, you have the information that you need to begin deploying Windows Firewall with Advanced Security using the guidance in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Guide.
segment.target: After you read this guide, and finish gathering, documenting, and mapping your organization's requirements, you have the information that you need to begin deploying Windows Firewall with Advanced Security using the guidance in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Guide.

segment.source: You can find the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Guide at these locations:
segment.target: You can find the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Guide at these locations:

segment.source: (Web page)
segment.target: (Web page)

segment.source: (Downloadable Word document)
segment.target: (Downloadable Word document)

segment.target: Understanding the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Process

segment.target: Learn how to get started with the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security design process.

segment.target: Identifying Your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Deployment Goals

segment.target: Learn how to identify your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security deployment goals.

segment.target: Mapping Your Deployment Goals to a Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design

segment.source: After you finish reviewing the existing Windows Firewall with Advanced Security deployment goals and you determine which goals are important to your specific deployment, you can map those goals to a specific Windows Firewall with Advanced Security design.
segment.target: After you finish reviewing the existing Windows Firewall with Advanced Security deployment goals and you determine which goals are important to your specific deployment, you can map those goals to a specific Windows Firewall with Advanced Security design.

segment.source: Evaluating Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Examples
segment.target: Evaluating Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Examples

segment.source: Learn how to use Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to improve the security of the computers connected to the network.
segment.target: Learn how to use Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to improve the security of the computers connected to the network.

segment.source: Designing a Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Strategy
segment.target: Designing a Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Strategy

segment.source: To select the most effective design for helping to protect the network, you must spend time collecting key information about your current computer environment.
segment.target: To select the most effective design for helping to protect the network, you must spend time collecting key information about your current computer environment.

segment.source: Planning Your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design
segment.target: Planning Your Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design

segment.source: After you have gathered the relevant information in the previous sections, and understand the basics of the designs as described earlier in this guide, you can select the design (or combination of designs) that meet your needs.
segment.target: After you have gathered the relevant information in the previous sections, and understand the basics of the designs as described earlier in this guide, you can select the design (or combination of designs) that meet your needs.

segment.source: Appendix A: Sample GPO Template Files for Settings Used in this Guide
segment.target: Appendix A: Sample GPO Template Files for Settings Used in this Guide

segment.source: You can import an XML file containing customized registry preferences into a Group Policy Object (GPO) by using the Preferences feature of the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: You can import an XML file containing customized registry preferences into a Group Policy Object (GPO) by using the Preferences feature of the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: Terminology used in this guide
segment.target: Terminology used in this guide

segment.source: The following table identifies and defines terms used throughout this guide.
segment.target: The following table identifies and defines terms used throughout this guide.

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Definition
segment.target: Definition

segment.source: Active Directory domain
segment.target: Active Directory domain

segment.source: A group of devices and users managed by an administrator by using Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).
segment.target: A group of devices and users managed by an administrator by using Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).

segment.source: Devices in a domain share a common directory database and security policies.
segment.target: Devices in a domain share a common directory database and security policies.

segment.source: Multiple domains can co-exist in a forest, with trust relationships that establish the forest as the security boundary.
segment.target: Multiple domains can co-exist in a forest, with trust relationships that establish the forest as the security boundary.

segment.source: Authentication
segment.target: Authentication

segment.source: A process that enables the sender of a message to prove its identity to the receiver.
segment.target: A process that enables the sender of a message to prove its identity to the receiver.

segment.source: For connection security in Windows, authentication is implemented by the IPsec protocol suite.
segment.target: For connection security in Windows, authentication is implemented by the IPsec protocol suite.

segment.source: Boundary zone
segment.target: Boundary zone

segment.source: A subset of the devices in an isolated domain that must be able to receive unsolicited and non-authenticated network traffic from devices that are not members of the isolated domain.
segment.target: A subset of the devices in an isolated domain that must be able to receive unsolicited and non-authenticated network traffic from devices that are not members of the isolated domain.

segment.source: Devices in the boundary zone request but do not require authentication.
segment.target: Devices in the boundary zone request but do not require authentication.

segment.source: They use IPsec to communicate with other devices in the isolated domain.
segment.target: They use IPsec to communicate with other devices in the isolated domain.

segment.source: Connection security rule
segment.target: Connection security rule

segment.source: A rule in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security that contains a set of conditions and an action to be applied to network packets that match the conditions.
segment.target: A rule in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security that contains a set of conditions and an action to be applied to network packets that match the conditions.

segment.source: The action can allow the packet, block the packet, or require the packet to be protected by IPsec.
segment.target: The action can allow the packet, block the packet, or require the packet to be protected by IPsec.

segment.source: In previous versions of Windows, this was called an IPsec rule.
segment.target: In previous versions of Windows, this was called an IPsec rule.

segment.source: Certificate-based isolation
segment.target: Certificate-based isolation

segment.source: A way to add devices that cannot use Kerberos V5 authentication to an isolated domain, by using an alternate authentication technique.
segment.target: A way to add devices that cannot use Kerberos V5 authentication to an isolated domain, by using an alternate authentication technique.

segment.source: Every device in the isolated domain and the devices that cannot use Kerberos V5 are provided with a device certificate that can be used to authenticate with each other.
segment.target: Every device in the isolated domain and the devices that cannot use Kerberos V5 are provided with a device certificate that can be used to authenticate with each other.

segment.source: Certificate-based isolation requires a way to create and distribute an appropriate certificate (if you choose not to purchase one from a commercial certificate provider).
segment.target: Certificate-based isolation requires a way to create and distribute an appropriate certificate (if you choose not to purchase one from a commercial certificate provider).

segment.source: Domain isolation
segment.target: Domain isolation

segment.source: A technique for helping protect the devices in an organization by requiring that the devices authenticate each other's identity before exchanging information, and refusing connection requests from devices that cannot authenticate.
segment.target: A technique for helping protect the devices in an organization by requiring that the devices authenticate each other's identity before exchanging information, and refusing connection requests from devices that cannot authenticate.

segment.source: Domain isolation takes advantage of Active Directory domain membership and the Kerberos V5 authentication protocol available to all members of the domain.
segment.target: Domain isolation takes advantage of Active Directory domain membership and the Kerberos V5 authentication protocol available to all members of the domain.

segment.source: Also see Isolated domain in this table.
segment.target: Also see Isolated domain in this table.

segment.source: Encryption zone
segment.target: Encryption zone

segment.source: A subset of the devices in an isolated domain that process sensitive data.
segment.target: A subset of the devices in an isolated domain that process sensitive data.

segment.source: Devices that are part of the encryption zone have all network traffic encrypted to prevent viewing by non-authorized users.
segment.target: Devices that are part of the encryption zone have all network traffic encrypted to prevent viewing by non-authorized users.

segment.source: Devices that are part of the encryption zone also typically are subject to the access control restrictions of server isolation.
segment.target: Devices that are part of the encryption zone also typically are subject to the access control restrictions of server isolation.

segment.source: Firewall rule
segment.target: Firewall rule

segment.source: A rule in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security that contains a set of conditions used to determine whether a network packet is allowed to pass through the firewall.
segment.target: A rule in Windows Firewall with Advanced Security that contains a set of conditions used to determine whether a network packet is allowed to pass through the firewall.

segment.source: By default, the firewall rules in Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows 8, Windows 7, and Windows Vista block unsolicited inbound network traffic.
segment.target: By default, the firewall rules in Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows 8, Windows 7, and Windows Vista block unsolicited inbound network traffic.

segment.source: Likewise, by default, all outbound network traffic is allowed.
segment.target: Likewise, by default, all outbound network traffic is allowed.

segment.source: The firewall included in previous versions of Windows only filtered inbound network traffic.
segment.target: The firewall included in previous versions of Windows only filtered inbound network traffic.

segment.source: Internet Protocol security (IPsec)
segment.target: Internet Protocol security (IPsec)

segment.source: A set of industry-standard, cryptography-based protection services and protocols.
segment.target: A set of industry-standard, cryptography-based protection services and protocols.

segment.source: IPsec protects all protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite except Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).
segment.target: IPsec protects all protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite except Address Resolution Protocol (ARP).

segment.source: IPsec policy
segment.target: IPsec policy

segment.source: A collection of connection security rules that provide the required protection to network traffic entering and leaving the device.
segment.target: A collection of connection security rules that provide the required protection to network traffic entering and leaving the device.

segment.source: The protection includes authentication of both the sending and receiving device, integrity protection of the network traffic exchanged between them, and can include encryption.
segment.target: The protection includes authentication of both the sending and receiving device, integrity protection of the network traffic exchanged between them, and can include encryption.

segment.source: Isolated domain
segment.target: Isolated domain

segment.source: An Active Directory domain (or an Active Directory forest, or set of domains with two-way trust relationships) that has Group Policy settings applied to help protect its member devices by using IPsec connection security rules.
segment.target: An Active Directory domain (or an Active Directory forest, or set of domains with two-way trust relationships) that has Group Policy settings applied to help protect its member devices by using IPsec connection security rules.

segment.source: Members of the isolated domain require authentication on all unsolicited inbound connections (with exceptions handled by the other zones).
segment.target: Members of the isolated domain require authentication on all unsolicited inbound connections (with exceptions handled by the other zones).

segment.source: In this guide, the term isolated domain refers to the IPsec concept of a group of devices that can share authentication.
segment.target: In this guide, the term isolated domain refers to the IPsec concept of a group of devices that can share authentication.

segment.source: The term Active Directory domain refers to the group of devices that share a security database by using Active Directory.
segment.target: The term Active Directory domain refers to the group of devices that share a security database by using Active Directory.

segment.source: Server isolation
segment.target: Server isolation

segment.source: A technique for using group membership to restrict access to a server that is typically already a member of an isolated domain.
segment.target: A technique for using group membership to restrict access to a server that is typically already a member of an isolated domain.

segment.source: The additional protection comes from using the authentication credentials of the requesting device to determine its group membership, and then only allowing access if the computer account (and optionally the user account) is a member of an authorized group.
segment.target: The additional protection comes from using the authentication credentials of the requesting device to determine its group membership, and then only allowing access if the computer account (and optionally the user account) is a member of an authorized group.

segment.source: Solicited network traffic
segment.target: Solicited network traffic

segment.source: Network traffic that is sent in response to a request.
segment.target: Network traffic that is sent in response to a request.

segment.source: By default, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows all solicited network traffic through.
segment.target: By default, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows all solicited network traffic through.

segment.source: Unsolicited network traffic
segment.target: Unsolicited network traffic

segment.source: Network traffic that is not a response to an earlier request, and that the receiving device cannot necessarily anticipate.
segment.target: Network traffic that is not a response to an earlier request, and that the receiving device cannot necessarily anticipate.

segment.source: By default, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security blocks all unsolicited network traffic.
segment.target: By default, Windows Firewall with Advanced Security blocks all unsolicited network traffic.

segment.source: Zone
segment.target: Zone

segment.source: A zone is a logical grouping of devices that share common IPsec policies because of their communications requirements.
segment.target: A zone is a logical grouping of devices that share common IPsec policies because of their communications requirements.

segment.source: For example, the boundary zone permits inbound connections from non-trusted devices.
segment.target: For example, the boundary zone permits inbound connections from non-trusted devices.

segment.source: The encryption zone requires that all connections be encrypted.
segment.target: The encryption zone requires that all connections be encrypted.

segment.source: This is not related to the term zone as used by Domain Name System (DNS).
segment.target: This is not related to the term zone as used by Domain Name System (DNS).

source.pc: Understanding the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Process

target.pc: Understanding the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Process
